Susceptibility of Helicoverpa armigera (Hubner) to Beauveria bassiana
(BALSAMO) Vuill
Helicoverpa armigera (Hub) a most
devastating pest, being polyphagous, it can invade
more than 200 host plants. Recently, the
management of the pest becomes most difficult
as it has developed the resistance towards most
of chemical insecticides. Therefore, exclusive
dependence of chemical pesticides is not likely
to provide sustained solutions against pest. To
overcome or minimise such problems, the study
on B. bassiana a fungal pathogen was carried
out under laboratory conditions, to know its
effectiveness against different stages of the pest
as a safe, effective and economical alternative
for chemical control.
The culture of Beauveria bassiana was
isolated from a commercial product, Dispel Â®-L,
(2.3x10
7 spores/ml) formulated by the Pesticides
India, Udaipur.
Potato dextrose agar (PDA) was used for
production of the fungus under laboratory. Culture
of the H. armigera was maintained under
laboratory conditions. First to fifth larval instars
of H. armigera were evaluated for their sensitivity
to the action of B. bassiana. The microbes were
tried at a spore load of 10
2
, 10
3
, 10
5 , 10
7 and 10
8
conidia per ml. The first and second instars were
sprayed in groups with one milliliter of suspension
with varying spore concentrations with the help
of chromatographic sprayer. The treated larvae
were allowed to feed on chickpea seedlings. The
third, fourth and fifth instar larvae were treated
individually with known quantity of fungal spore
suspension (50 l/larvae) containing differential
spore load. Infected larvae were reared individually
on artificial diet in glass vials. Similarly, treated
larvae of same age with 0.02 per cent tween 80
served as control for all the treatments. Bioassay
was carried out in four replications with 10 larvae
each. Mortality of the larvae due to fungal infection
was recorded as per symptoms described by Kish
(1975).
